intro: Phyllota georgii, commonly known as the Mexican yellowflower, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its pod fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows as a low shrub with hairy stems and yellow, pea-like flowers. Its leaves are trifoliate, meaning they are divided into three leaflets, and it thrives in well-drained soils. Phyllota georgii is adapted to drought conditions, making it a resilient species in desert environments.
